title: Chemistry (CY)
description: Comprehensive GATE Chemistry assessment covering General Aptitude and Core Chemistry subjects. This assessment includes 10 aptitude questions (15% weight) and 55 core chemistry questions (85% weight) following the official GATE pattern.
whatIsDescription: GATE (Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering) Chemistry is a national-level examination that primarily tests the comprehensive understanding of various undergraduate subjects in chemistry and related fields. This assessment follows the official GATE pattern with General Aptitude and Core Chemistry questions.

typicalCareers.title: Research Scientist
typicalCareers.description: Advanced chemistry research positions in academia and industry

typicalCareers.title: PhD Candidate
typicalCareers.description: Pursue higher studies in chemistry and related fields

typicalCareers.title: Chemical Engineer
typicalCareers.description: Senior technical roles in chemical process design and optimization

whoShouldConsider: Students seeking admission to M.Tech/M.E programs in chemistry
Professionals looking for PSU jobs in chemical sector
Researchers in chemistry and related fields
idealTraits: Good understanding of chemical principles and reactions

aptitude.title: General Aptitude Assessment
aptitude.description: Test your general aptitude including verbal ability, quantitative aptitude, and analytical reasoning skills. This section carries 15% weight in the total assessment.

questions.text: If GATE is coded as 1207205, how is EXAM coded?
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Coding
questions.explanation: Each letter is coded as its position in alphabet: E=5, X=24, A=1, M=13. Hence 5241013.

questions.text: Find the next number in the series: 2, 6, 12, 20, 30, ?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Series

questions.text: In a class of 50 students, 30 play cricket, 25 play football, and 10 play both. How many play neither?
questions.subject: Logical Reasoning - Set Theory
questions.explanation: Using set theory: Total = Cricket only + Football only + Both + Neither. 50 = (30-10) + (25-10) + 10 + Neither. Neither = 5.

questions.text: Which word does NOT belong to the group: Temperature, Pressure, Density, Force?
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Classification
questions.explanation: Force is a vector quantity while others are scalar quantities.

questions.text: The ratio of boys to girls in a class is 3:2. If there are 15 boys, how many girls are there?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Ratio
questions.explanation: Ratio 3:2 means for every 3 boys, there are 2 girls. 15 boys ÷ 3 = 5 sets. So girls = 5 × 2 = 10.

questions.text: If all chemists are scientists and some scientists are mathematicians, which statement is definitely true?
questions.subject: Logical Reasoning - Syllogism
questions.explanation: The relationship between chemists and mathematicians cannot be determined from the given statements.

questions.text: A train travels 60 km in 45 minutes. What is its speed in km/h?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Speed
questions.explanation: Speed = Distance/Time. 60 km / (45/60) hours = 60 × (60/45) = 80 km/h.

questions.text: Choose the word most similar in meaning to 'METICULOUS':
questions.subject: Verbal Ability - Synonyms
questions.explanation: Meticulous means very careful and precise.

questions.text: If P = 2Q and Q = 3R, what is the value of P when R = 5?
questions.subject: Numerical Ability - Algebra

questions.text: A pie chart shows: Research 40%, Teaching 30%, Admin 20%, Others 10%. If the total budget is ₹1 crore, how much is for Teaching?
questions.subject: Data Interpretation - Percentage
questions.explanation: Teaching = 30% of ₹1 crore = 0.30 × ₹100 lakhs = ₹30 lakhs.

core.title: Core Chemistry Assessment
core.description: Comprehensive assessment of core chemistry subjects including Physical Chemistry, Organic Chemistry, Inorganic Chemistry, Analytical Chemistry, and related topics. This section carries 85% weight in the total assessment.

questions.text: What is the ground state electronic configuration of Cr (Z=24)?
questions.subject: Atomic Structure - Electronic Configuration
questions.explanation: Chromium shows exceptional configuration due to half-filled d-orbital stability: [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s¹ instead of [Ar] 3d⁴ 4s².

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest first ionization energy?
questions.subject: Periodic Properties - Ionization Energy
questions.explanation: Noble gases have the highest ionization energies due to stable electronic configuration. Ne > F > N > O.

questions.text: Calculate the molarity of a solution containing 5.85g NaCl in 500 mL water (Molar mass NaCl = 58.5 g/mol):
questions.subject: Solutions - Molarity
questions.explanation: Moles = 5.85/58.5 = 0.1 mol. Volume = 500 mL = 0.5 L. Molarity = 0.1/0.5 = 0.2 M.

questions.text: For the reaction N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, if Kc = 0.5, what is Kp at 400K? (R = 0.082 L atm/mol K)
questions.subject: Chemical Equilibrium - Kp and Kc

questions.text: Which molecule has zero dipole moment?
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Dipole Moment
questions.explanation: CO₂ is linear and symmetrical, so bond dipoles cancel out resulting in zero net dipole moment.

questions.text: What is the hybridization of central atom in SF₆?
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Hybridization
questions.explanation: SF₆ has 6 bond pairs and 0 lone pairs. Steric number = 6, hence sp³d² hybridization (octahedral geometry).

questions.text: Calculate ΔH for the reaction: C + O₂ → CO₂, given ΔHf(CO₂) = -393.5 kJ/mol:
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Enthalpy
questions.explanation: ΔH of reaction = Σ ΔHf(products) - Σ ΔHf(reactants) = -393.5 - 0 = -393.5 kJ/mol.

questions.text: For a first-order reaction, if the rate constant k = 0.693 min⁻¹, what is the half-life?
questions.subject: Chemical Kinetics - Half-life
questions.explanation: For first-order: t₁/₂ = 0.693/k = 0.693/0.693 = 1.0 min.

questions.text: Which of the following is an ore of aluminum?
questions.subject: Metallurgy - Ores
questions.explanation: Bauxite (Al₂O₃·2H₂O) is the primary ore of aluminum.

questions.text: Which reagent is used for the Clemmensen reduction?
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Reduction Reactions
questions.explanation: Clemmensen reduction uses Zn-Hg/HCl to reduce carbonyl groups to alkanes under acidic conditions.

questions.text: The pH of 0.01 M HCl solution is:
questions.subject: Ionic Equilibrium - pH

questions.text: Which has the highest boiling point?
questions.subject: States of Matter - Boiling Point
questions.explanation: Boiling point increases with molecular mass due to stronger Van der Waals forces. C₄H₁₀ has highest MW.

questions.text: The oxidation state of Mn in KMnO₄ is:
questions.subject: Redox Reactions - Oxidation State

questions.text: Which quantum number determines the shape of an orbital?
questions.subject: Atomic Structure - Quantum Numbers
questions.explanation: The azimuthal quantum number (l) determines the shape of the orbital (s, p, d, f).

questions.text: For an ideal gas, which relationship is correct?
questions.subject: Gaseous State - Gas Laws
questions.explanation: All three are gas laws: Boyle's (A), Charles' (B), and Gay-Lussac's (C) law.

questions.text: The entropy change for an irreversible adiabatic process is:
questions.subject: Thermodynamics - Entropy
questions.explanation: For irreversible processes, entropy of universe always increases (ΔS > 0).

questions.text: Which has the maximum number of unpaired electrons?
questions.subject: Coordination Chemistry - Electronic Configuration
questions.explanation: Fe³⁺: [Ar] 3d⁵ has 5 unpaired electrons (maximum). Fe²⁺: 4, Co²⁺: 3, Ni²⁺: 2.

questions.text: What is the IUPAC name of CH₃-CH(CH₃)-CH₂-OH?
questions.subject: Organic Nomenclature - IUPAC
questions.explanation: Main chain is 3 carbons with OH at C-1 and methyl at C-2: 2-methylpropan-1-ol.

questions.text: Lucas test is used to distinguish between:
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Tests
questions.explanation: Lucas reagent (ZnCl₂/HCl) reacts fastest with tertiary, then secondary, slowest with primary alcohols.

questions.text: The number of stereoisomers of 2,3-dichlorobutane is:
questions.subject: Stereochemistry - Stereoisomers
questions.explanation: 2,3-dichlorobutane has 2 chiral centers. Total = 2² = 4, but one pair is meso, so 3 stereoisomers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a colligative property?
questions.subject: Solutions - Colligative Properties
questions.explanation: Refractive index depends on the nature of solute, not just number of particles. Colligative properties depend only on the number of solute particles.

questions.text: The rate of a reaction becomes 4 times when temperature increases from 300K to 320K. The activation energy is approximately:
questions.subject: Chemical Kinetics - Arrhenius Equation
questions.explanation: Using Arrhenius equation: ln(k₂/k₁) = (Ea/R)(1/T₁ - 1/T₂). ln(4) = (Ea/8.314)(1/300 - 1/320). Ea ≈ 52.9 kJ/mol.

questions.text: In the extraction of copper from copper pyrites, the extraction involves:
questions.subject: Metallurgy - Copper Extraction
questions.explanation: Copper pyrites (CuFeS₂) extraction: Roasting → Smelting → Bessemerisation → Electrolytic refining.

questions.text: Which of the following is strongest acid?
questions.subject: Inorganic Chemistry - Oxyacids
questions.explanation: Acidity of oxyacids increases with number of oxygen atoms. HClO₄ > HClO₃ > HClO₂ > HClO.

questions.text: Bakelite is a polymer of:
questions.subject: Polymers - Condensation Polymers
questions.explanation: Bakelite is a thermosetting polymer formed by condensation of phenol and formaldehyde.

questions.text: The coordination number of Fe in K₃[Fe(CN)₆] is:
questions.subject: Coordination Chemistry - Coordination Number
questions.explanation: In K₃[Fe(CN)₆], Fe is surrounded by 6 CN⁻ ligands, so coordination number is 6.

questions.text: The number of π bonds in benzene is:
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Aromatic Compounds
questions.explanation: Benzene has 3 π bonds (delocalized) formed by overlap of p-orbitals in the ring.

questions.text: The unit of rate constant for a second-order reaction is:
questions.subject: Chemical Kinetics - Rate Constant Units
questions.explanation: For second-order: rate = k[A]². Units: mol L⁻¹ s⁻¹ = k × (mol L⁻¹)². Therefore k = L mol⁻¹ s⁻¹.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Lewis acid?
questions.subject: Acid-Base Chemistry - Lewis Theory
questions.explanation: Lewis acid accepts electron pairs. BF₃ has incomplete octet and can accept electron pairs.

questions.text: The number of isomers possible for C₄H₁₀ is:
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Isomerism
questions.explanation: C₄H₁₀ has 2 isomers: n-butane and isobutane (2-methylpropane).

questions.text: The pH of a buffer solution containing 0.1 M CH₃COOH and 0.1 M CH₃COONa is: (Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵)
questions.subject: Ionic Equilibrium - Buffer Solutions
questions.explanation: For buffer: pH = pKa + log([salt]/[acid]) = -log(1.8×10⁻⁵) + log(0.1/0.1) = 4.74 + 0 = 4.74.

questions.text: The hybridization of carbon in C₂H₂ is:
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Hybridization
questions.explanation: C₂H₂ (acetylene) has linear geometry with sp hybridization (2 σ bonds, 2 π bonds).

questions.text: The number of moles of electrons required to reduce 1 mole of Cr₂O₇²⁻ to Cr³⁺ is:
questions.subject: Redox Reactions - Electron Transfer
questions.explanation: Cr₂O₇²⁻ → 2Cr³⁺. Each Cr changes from +6 to +3 (3 electrons each). Total: 2 × 3 = 6 electrons.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reducing agent?
questions.subject: Redox Reactions - Reducing Agents
questions.explanation: Na₂S₂O₃ (sodium thiosulfate) is a common reducing agent. Others are oxidizing agents.

questions.text: The number of σ bonds in ethene (C₂H₄) is:
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Sigma Bonds
questions.explanation: C₂H₄ has: 4 C-H σ bonds + 1 C-C σ bond = 5 σ bonds total.

questions.text: The order of reaction with respect to A in the rate equation: rate = k[A]²[B] is:
questions.subject: Chemical Kinetics - Order of Reaction
questions.explanation: The order with respect to A is the exponent of [A] in the rate equation, which is 2.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest melting point?
questions.subject: Solid State - Ionic Compounds
questions.explanation: Melting point increases with charge and decreases with size. Mg²⁺ has highest charge/size ratio.

questions.text: The number of lone pairs on oxygen in H₂O is:
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - VSEPR Theory
questions.explanation: Oxygen in H₂O has 6 valence electrons, 2 used in bonds, leaving 4 electrons (2 lone pairs).

questions.text: The standard electrode potential of hydrogen electrode is:
questions.subject: Electrochemistry - Standard Electrode Potential
questions.explanation: Standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) is assigned 0.00 V by convention as the reference electrode.

questions.text: The number of π electrons in benzene is:
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Aromaticity
questions.explanation: Benzene has 6 π electrons (4n+2 rule, n=1), which makes it aromatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is a nucleophile?
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Nucleophiles
questions.explanation: Nucleophiles are electron-rich species that donate electron pairs. NH₃ has lone pair on nitrogen.

questions.text: The number of stereocenters in glucose is:
questions.subject: Stereochemistry - Chiral Centers
questions.explanation: Glucose has 4 stereocenters (chiral carbons) at positions 2, 3, 4, and 5.

questions.text: The rate of reaction increases with temperature because:

options.text: More molecules have sufficient energy to overcome activation barrier

questions.subject: Chemical Kinetics - Temperature Effect
questions.explanation: Higher temperature increases the fraction of molecules with energy ≥ Ea, increasing reaction rate.

questions.text: The coordination number of platinum in [Pt(NH₃)₄]²⁺ is:
questions.subject: Coordination Chemistry - Coordination Number
questions.explanation: In [Pt(NH₃)₄]²⁺, platinum is surrounded by 4 NH₃ ligands, so coordination number is 4.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of addition polymer?
questions.subject: Polymers - Addition vs Condensation
questions.explanation: Polyethylene is formed by addition polymerization of ethylene. Others are condensation polymers.

questions.text: The number of nodes in a 3p orbital is:
questions.subject: Atomic Structure - Quantum Mechanics
questions.explanation: For 3p orbital: n=3, l=1. Number of nodes = n-l-1 = 3-1-1 = 1 radial node + 1 angular node = 2 total.

questions.text: The oxidation state of sulfur in H₂SO₄ is:
questions.subject: Redox Reactions - Oxidation State

questions.text: Which of the following is a strong electrolyte?
questions.subject: Ionic Equilibrium - Electrolytes
questions.explanation: HCl is a strong acid that completely ionizes in water. Others are weak electrolytes.

questions.text: The number of isomers possible for C₃H₈ is:
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Isomerism
questions.explanation: C₃H₈ (propane) has only one possible structure - no structural isomers exist.

questions.text: The hybridization of nitrogen in NH₃ is:
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Hybridization
questions.explanation: NH₃ has 3 bond pairs + 1 lone pair = 4 electron pairs, hence sp³ hybridization (tetrahedral geometry).

questions.text: The number of moles of KMnO₄ required to oxidize 1 mole of Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ is:
questions.subject: Redox Reactions - Stoichiometry
questions.explanation: MnO₄⁻ + 5Fe²⁺ + 8H⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 5Fe³⁺ + 4H₂O. 1 mole KMnO₄ oxidizes 5 moles Fe²⁺, so 1 mole Fe²⁺ needs 0.2 moles KMnO₄.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest bond energy?
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Bond Energy
questions.explanation: H-H has the highest bond energy (436 kJ/mol). Bond energy decreases down the group: H-H > F-F > Cl-Cl > Br-Br.

questions.text: The number of π bonds in acetylene (C₂H₂) is:
questions.subject: Chemical Bonding - Pi Bonds
questions.explanation: C₂H₂ has a triple bond: 1 σ bond + 2 π bonds between the carbon atoms.

questions.text: The coordination number of central atom in [Co(NH₃)₆]³⁺ is:
questions.subject: Coordination Chemistry - Coordination Number
questions.explanation: In [Co(NH₃)₆]³⁺, cobalt is surrounded by 6 NH₃ ligands, so coordination number is 6.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of electrophilic substitution?
questions.subject: Organic Chemistry - Reaction Mechanisms
questions.explanation: Nitration of benzene involves electrophilic substitution where NO₂⁺ acts as electrophile. Others are different reaction types.

results.title: Results & Analysis
results.description: Comprehensive analysis of your performance across all sections with detailed insights and recommendations.
